content.description: This route ascends the rock to the left of deliverance. It follows a sharp juggy arete and then traverses out to the middle on sharp jugs. This route is defined by big moves on jugs. There are holds all the way up the arete, but they'd probably brake if you pulled on them.
content.location: Take the path to the north face of deliverance. This route is to the west (left) of the main deliverance wall. Go up a short grassy slope to get to the bottom. The top anchors are accessible by following path to to the top of deliverance rock, but continuing west through some bushes.

content.description:
The right bolted climb on Deliverence rock, Squeal Like a Pig ascends a dihdral with very few holds and awkward stemming. Start at the finger pocket just above your head (unless you freakishly tall), and enjoy it, because its the best hold you'll have for about 35 feet.  So to make up for this dearth of good holds, you'll have to stem your heart out.

The bolt spacing and location on this route is safe but still has a very spicy feel, and there are definitely areas where you would not want to take the fall.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with chains.  Top-roping Sqeal like a pig will probably cause a LOT of rope drag unless you bring about a 20' sling to hang past the slab near the top.

content.description: "Sneaky Pouch" is located 40' right of "Lucy". It currently climbs a ramp to start, although a direct variation is possible on TR. The crux involves really good climbing through a small but tough overhang, on shallow pockets.
content.location: Same approach as for Lucy, which faces south across a small ravine from Castle Rock. Start up the left side of Castle Rock ridge and then branch off to the left...

content.description: The crux of Lucy is the first 20', climbing out the left edge of a cave. Really dynamic movement with some delicate footwork to exit the crux and gain the upper face.
content.location:
Lucy is found on the south-facing upper terminus of the Deliverance ridge("Deliverance" is on the north-facing side). When climbing Lucy you are across a gully from the Castle Rock ridge). To find the climb, you can either hike down from the top of castle rock or ascend up the north side of the Castle Rock ridge for 200 yards. At this point leave the main trail and traverse north towards an obvious, 30' high block. 4th class over a small ridge (15' high) and continue north to the base of the block and then ascend upwards, eventually angling right. When you get to the top of the ridge, you will be looking across a gully to Castle Rock to the south and you will be above Lucy. You can either look for the rap anchors (sketchy), or continue around and down to the base (less sketchy).

Ulysse Worsfold working the start of Lucy

content.description:
Crimpers, tiny pockets and bad edges with a big reach define this route. The rock for the most part is pretty solid and not a problem, but the climbing will test your edging ability and endurance. There is a definite crux down low, which doesn't exactly set you up for success for the 5.12+ climbing above.

After the second to last bolt you traverse to the left across the face and join the top of Deliverance. There is a direct finish to the route which follows a short vertical seam to the top, avoiding the traverse which has been top roped. The addition of a bolt would be needed to make this leadable, as well as a separate anchor.
content.location: Just to the right of Deliverance.

content.description: Cool moves on very nice rock.
content.protection:
8 Bolts

chains + climb-tech mussy hooks anchor
